title: 105_s2190
content: Subtitle C of the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 introduces the Microenterprise Technical Assistance and Capacity Building Program, also known as the PRIME Act. This program aims to provide technical assistance to microenterprises. The PRIME Act, under Subtitle C of the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994, defines key terms such as 'Administrator', 'capacity building services', 'collaborative', and 'disadvantaged entrepreneur' for the purpose of providing technical assistance to microenterprises. The PRIME Act defines key terms related to microenterprises, such as 'Fund', 'Indian tribe', 'intermediary', 'low-income person', 'microentrepreneur', and 'microenterprise' as entities with fewer than 5 employees. The PRIME Act defines a 'microenterprise development organization or program' as a nonprofit entity that provides services to disadvantaged entrepreneurs. 'Training and technical assistance' refers to support for enhancing business skills and accessing financial services. The term 'very low-income person' is defined as someone with an income not exceeding 150 percent of the poverty line. The Administrator will establish a grant program for microenterprise technical assistance and capacity building. Grants will be provided to qualified organizations from the Fund. The assistance can be used for various purposes. Qualified organizations receiving grants under this subtitle must use the funds for training and technical assistance for disadvantaged entrepreneurs, capacity building for microenterprise development organizations, researching best practices in microenterprise, and other activities approved by the Administrator. Qualified organizations eligible for assistance under this subtitle include nonprofit microenterprise development organizations, intermediaries, community-accountable microenterprise programs working with local governments or tribes, and Indian tribes without access to private organizations. The Administrator allocates assistance from the Fund to ensure that activities described in section 174(1) receive at least 75% of the funding, and activities in section 174(2) receive at least 15%. No single organization can receive more than 10% of total funds in a fiscal year. At least 50% of grants must benefit very low-income individuals, including those on Indian reservations. The Administrator ensures that at least 50% of grants benefit very low-income individuals, including those on Indian reservations. Qualified organizations can provide grants to small and emerging microenterprise organizations, with a limit of 7.5% for administrative expenses. Grant recipients must include large and small microenterprise organizations serving urban, rural, and Indian communities. Small microenterprise organizations serve diverse populations in urban, rural, and Indian tribal communities. Small microenterprise organizations serve diverse populations in urban, rural, and Indian tribal communities. SEC. 177. MATCHING REQUIREMENTS. Financial assistance under this subtitle requires a 50 percent match from non-Federal sources. Matching funds can come from various sources including fees, grants, gifts, loans, and in-kind resources. The Administrator may reduce or eliminate the matching requirements for applicants with severe constraints on funds, but no more than 10 percent of total funds can be exempted in any fiscal year. Financial assistance under this subtitle typically requires a 50 percent match from non-Federal sources, but exceptions can be made for applicants with severe funding constraints. Up to 10 percent of total funds can be exempted in any fiscal year. "Financial assistance applications must be submitted as per Fund procedures. Recordkeeping requirements apply to organizations receiving assistance. Additional funds are authorized for fiscal years 1999-2002. Implementation details are outlined." The Administrator will establish regulations to implement the requirements of this subtitle. Section 121(a)(2)(A) of the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to increase administrative expenses. Conforming amendments will be made. SEC. 3. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to Section 104(d) of the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994, including increasing the number of individuals with expertise in microenterprises and microenterprise development.
